title: Why $127 B Still Hasn’t Closed the Affordable-Housing Gap?
description: To build this table, I downloaded every annual HUD award file (CDBG, HOME, ESG, HOPWA, HTF, etc.) one year at a time, stitched them into a single ​combined_awards.csv dataset, and ran the totals you see here. Considering that tens of billions of federal dollars are at stake, it’s surprising HUD doesn’t offer a one-click, all-years download—manual collection was the only option. The merged dataset (link below) drives the percentages and unit counts shown in the “Reality Check” column, and each row also cites a national report where you can dig deeper.

rows.reality_check: Affordable rentals are disappearing faster than we build them.
rows.data_message: The U.S. lost 3.9 million units with rents under $600 (2011–2019) through demolition, condo conversion, or large rent hikes—erasing many new affordable units.

rows.reality_check: Most of the dollars never build a new ELI unit.
rows.data_message: Only about 25 % of CDBG spending goes to housing, and an even smaller slice serves extremely-low-income renters; the rest funds sidewalks, parks, and other projects.

rows.reality_check: The programs that do build rental housing are small.
rows.data_message: HOME adds ≈ 17 k units per year; HTF adds ≈ 2 k units—tiny next to the 7.1 million-unit shortage.

rows.reality_check: Each new ELI unit costs six figures.
rows.data_message: Recent HOME projects average $150 k–$200 k per unit; at $150 k, the full $127 B would create only ~850 k units—12 % of the need. (By comparison, if $127 billion were spent on Boxabl Baby Box units at ~$20,000 each, it could create over 6 million homes—covering about 90% of the affordable housing need.)
From 2001 to 2021, the number of extremely-low-income renter households rose by about 1.7 million, adding fresh demand every year.
